channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Hezbollah Fires on Tel Aviv; Israeli General Hints at Use of Ground Troops
item.description: Israeli defenses shot down the missile aimed at Tel Aviv, but its firing was a sign of Hezbollah’s long reach after days of withering Israeli strikes. In the north, the top Israeli general told troops to prepare for a possible incursion into Lebanon.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Israeli Bulldozers Flatten Mile After Mile in the West Bank
item.description: Videos from Tulkarm and Jenin show bulldozers destroying infrastructure and businesses, as well as soldiers impeding local emergency responders.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon, Lauren Leatherby and Aric Toler

item.title: U.N. Live Updates: Zelensky Calls for Global Focus to Stay on Ukraine
item.description: To reverse Russia’s steady battlefield advances, the Ukrainian leader needs the support of Western allies whose attention is also demanded by other wars.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times

item.title: Gisèle Pelicot Has Become a Feminist Hero in France Amid Rape Trial
item.description: Gisèle Pelicot waived anonymity to make public the trial of her former husband and the 50 men accused of joining him in raping her. Her poise and courage have made her an icon.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:description: Gisèle Pelicot, center, with her lawyers outside the courthouse in Avignon, France, this month.

item.title: Iran’s Dilemma: How to Preserve Its Proxies and Avoid Full-Scale War
item.description: Iran says Israel wants to trap it into a direct conflict by bombing Hezbollah, even as a new Iranian president tries outreach to the West.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Masoud Pezeshkian of Iran told the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday that Israel was seeking to trap his country into a wider war.

item.title: Senegal’s Young President Wants a New World Order
item.description: In his first interview with Western media since becoming president of Senegal, Bassirou Diomaye Faye said the United Nations has to change to reflect changing world demographics.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:credit: Carmen Abd Ali for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Bassirou Diomaye Faye of Senegal in the presidential palace in Dakar, the capital, on Friday.

item.title: Justin Trudeau’s Party Faces Confidence Vote as Canada Turns on Its Leader
item.description: Canada’s Liberals are reeling from a string of setbacks, as the party faces a confidence vote in Parliament on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada arriving for a meeting in Ottawa last week with the emir of Qatar, Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad al-Thani.

item.title: Online Scammers Posed as Brad Pitt to Get Cash, Spanish Police Say
item.description: The authorities in Spain said they had arrested five people who posed as the famous American actor online and swindled two women out of more than $350,000.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Chaundler and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Brad Pitt in Los Angeles last week. His publicist said the actor had no authorized social media accounts.

item.title: China Launched a Rocket With a Dummy Warhead Into the Pacific
item.description: The ballistic missile launch is a sign of the commitment of Xi Jinping, China’s leader, to continue strengthening the country’s Rocket Force and to project power in Asia.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: The Chinese military’s DF-41 intercontinental ballistic missiles at a parade at Tiananmen Square in Beijing in 2019.

item.title: Taiwan and U.S. Work to Counter China’s Drone Dominance
item.description: Officials hope that Taiwan can become a bigger player in the supply chain for drones, a move that would also help blunt any threats posed to the island by China.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: A drone developed in Taiwan, on display in 2022. Taiwan plans to expand its military drone arsenal.

item.title: A Litmus Test in Japan: Should Spouses Be Able to Have Different Surnames?
item.description: The nine candidates vying to become prime minister have been differentiated by their stances on a law requiring married couples to share a family name.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Kiuko Notoya
item.media:description: A wedding ceremony at a Shinto shrine in Tokyo.

item.title: Ukrainian Poet and Rock Star Fights Near Front and Performs Behind It
item.description: Serhiy Zhadan, 50, is a beloved Ukrainian poet as well as a novelist, lyricist and rock star. Furious over the invasion, he enlisted to fight even as his band still plays and his readings fill halls.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Serhiy Zhadan, a Ukrainian poet, rock star and now a soldier, at a military position in the Kharkiv region of Ukraine, in July. There is a Russian bounty on his head.

item.title: In Beirut, Israel’s Strikes Stoke Fears of War
item.description: With Monday’s attacks across southern Lebanon, the prospect of the escalating conflict enveloping the city has suddenly become real for many Beirut residents.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Hwaida Saad
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A gas station Beirut, Lebanon, on Monday. Some Lebanese fled, or prepared to do so, amid the Israeli strikes.

item.title: How a Leftist Jolted Sri Lanka’s Politics and Presidency
item.description: Anura Kumara Dissanayake offered his broad leftist coalition as the best hope for a different political culture, one not ruled by nepotism and corruption.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Pamodi Waravita
item.category: Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna (Sri Lankan Political Party)
item.media:description: Anura Kumara Dissanayake departing the election commission office after winning the Sri Lankan presidential election in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Sunday.

item.title: Festival d’Automne in Paris Honors Rabih Mroué and Lina Majdalanie
item.description: A retrospective in Paris honors Lina Majdalanie and Rabih Mroué, whose theater works have examined the region’s troubles for decades.
item.dc:creator: Laura Cappelle
item.media:credit: Elliott Verdier for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We don’t tell stories. We think together,” said Rabih Mroué, right. He and his partner, Lina Majdalanie, left, were “interested in what underpins events,” Mroué said.

item.title: Hezbollah’s Military Capability: What We Know
item.description: The Iran-backed militants have perhaps the largest arsenal of any armed group in the world, excluding governments, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: A rocket hit a house in Sa’ar, Israel.

item.title: Lebanon’s Growing Civilian Death Toll Includes Children and Rescue Workers
item.description: Lebanese organizations have begun to identify children, humanitarians and journalists among a growing number of civilians killed in Israel’s intense bombardment.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: An impact crater from an Israeli strike in Jiyeh, Lebanon, on Wednesday.

item.title: What Is Zelensky’s ‘Victory Plan’ for Ukraine’s War With Russia?
item.description: The Ukrainian leader aims to present President Biden with a strategy to improve his country’s position ahead of any peace negotiations with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A railway substation that was partly destroyed by a Russian glide bomb, in Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: Astronomers Spot a Black Hole with a Cosmic Wingspan
item.description: Astronomers have discovered a black hole emitting energy in jets longer than the width of 140 Milky Way galaxies.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye

item.title: In Lebanon, a Family Flees Israeli Airstrikes
item.description: After years of decline, Lebanon is ill-equipped to deal with a wave of displaced people. One family left their farm and found themselves homeless in Beirut.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:description: A shelter for displaced people at a school in Beirut on Tuesday.

item.title: France Rape Trial Renews Push to Revise Legal Definition of Rape
item.description: Gisèle Pelicot waived anonymity to make public the trial of her former husband and the 50 men accused of joining him in raping her. The trial has revived the question of consent within French law and turned Ms. Pelicot into a feminist icon. Catherine Porter, an international correspondent for The New York Times based in France, explains.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter, Rebecca Suner, Christina Shaman, Laura Salaberry and Farah Otero-Amad

item.title: In the Footsteps of Dostoyevsky in Three German Spa Towns
item.description: The Russian novelist, a compulsive gambler, lost everything in the opulent spa and gambling towns of Baden-Baden, Bad Homburg and Wiesbaden. An admirer of his books follows his footsteps.
item.dc:creator: Charly Wilder
item.media:credit: Felix Schmitt for The New York Times
item.media:description: The casino in the Kurhaus at Baden-Baden, one of three spa towns where the 19th-century Russian novelist, Fyodor Dostoyevsky, gambled his money away.

item.title: Israel Says It Shot Down Missile Over Tel Aviv
item.description: The missile fired from Lebanon was the first time Hezbollah had launched an attack aimed at Tel Aviv, the military said.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim, Gabby Sobelman and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: An Israeli defense system intercepts a missile over Tel Aviv on Wednesday.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: The U.N. General Assembly Convenes
item.description: Plus, news outlets experiment with WhatsApp.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden addressed the U.N. yesterday.

item.title: Study Finds Climate Change Doubled Likelihood of Recent European Floods
item.description: Storm Boris dumped record amounts of rain over Central and Eastern Europe this month. A new study found climate change made the deluge more likely.
item.dc:creator: Austyn Gaffney
item.media:description: Firefighters on the flooded streets of Lewin Brzeski, Poland, on Sept. 19.

item.title: As U.N. Meets, Israel Pounds Targets in Lebanon, Sending Civilians Fleeing
item.description: Israel said it was striking Hezbollah targets with “high intensity” to keep the campaign as short as possible, as the Lebanese militants maintained their own cross-border barrage.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward, Ben Hubbard, Aaron Boxerman and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Lebanese army and emergency workers at the scene of an Israeli airstrike in Beirut’s southern suburbs on Tuesday.

item.title: What Lebanon Looks Like After Israel’s Historic Airstrikes
item.description: The destruction from one of the most intense air raids in modern warfare stretches across southern Lebanon and in pockets of the east.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Leatherby and Aric Toler

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: The U.N. General Assembly Convenes
item.description: Plus, news outlets experiment with WhatsApp.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joe Biden at the 79th session of the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday.

item.title: Zelensky Addresses the Security Council, Calling for Attention to Stay on Ukraine
item.description: “Russia can only be forced into peace.” President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine urged the Council members to sustain their backing for his country’s resistance to Russia’s full-scale invasion.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents of Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine, walked on Tuesday past a railway substation that was partly destroyed by a Russian glide bomb.

item.title: Israel’s Attacks on Hezbollah Achieved Short-Term Aims, Officials Say
item.description: Some hawkish generals think that Hezbollah can be forced to back down, current and former Israeli officials said, while others in the government think Israel must reach a deal with Hamas before expanding the war.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: An area hit by an Israeli strike in Beirut’s southern suburbs on Tuesday.

item.title: Israel Says It Killed Another Top Leader of Hezbollah
item.description: For nearly a year, Hezbollah has been attacking Israel in solidarity with Hamas in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A procession for Ibrahim Aqeel, a senior Hezbollah commander, on Sunday after he was killed in an Israeli airstrike in Beirut.

item.title: U.K.’s Starmer Sprinkles Kamala Harris-style ‘Joy’ Into Conference Speech
item.description: After a somewhat bumpy start to his premiership, Keir Starmer tried to reclaim the narrative, acknowledging voters’ desire for hope and promising change was on the way.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain at the annual Labour Party conference in Liverpool, England, on Tuesday. “I know that the cost-of-living crisis drew a veil over the joy and wonder in our lives,” he said.

item.title: Russia Signs Satellite Deal With Three West African Military Governments
item.description: The partnership between Russia’s space agency and the governments of Burkina Faso, Mali and Niger deepens these countries’ turn toward the Kremlin in their effort to fight off Islamist insurgencies.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: The military leaders of Niger, Mali and Burkina Faso at the first summit of the three countries’ new security alliance in July.

item.title: Israel’s Strikes on Lebanon Are Some of the Deadliest in Decades: What to Know
item.description: What we know about the strikes, the death toll and how it is calculated.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Euan Ward
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Members of a Lebanese civil defense and firefighting unit worked on Tuesday at the site of an Israeli strike in Beirut’s southern suburbs.

item.title: Families of Hostages and Gazans Feel Forgotten as War Heats Up in Lebanon
item.description: Talks to reach a potential cease-fire in Gaza and free the remaining 100 or so hostages have stalled.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Families of hostages held by Hamas in the Gaza Strip rally in Tel Aviv on Saturday to call for a deal for their release.

item.title: Zelensky Says Western Allies Must Allow Ukrainian Strikes Deep Into Russia
item.description: The leaders of Ukraine and Denmark said in a joint interview that allied nations must lift restrictions on arms, increase their production and help Ukraine build weapons inside the country.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Since the Russian invasion of Ukraine in 2022, the United States has only gradually given Ukraine certain weapons systems and slowly loosened some restrictions on their use.

item.title: Escalation in the Middle East Looms Over the General Assembly Meeting
item.description: The war in Gaza has endured more than 11 months, and violence between Israel and Hezbollah, the Iranian-backed Lebanese militia, has risen sharply over the last week.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hezbollah fighters paying tribute to a slain leader.

item.title: Moo Deng Is the Internet’s Favorite Pygmy Hippopotamus
item.description: Moo Deng, whose name translates to “bouncy pork,” has united the internet while following a familiar path to stardom.
item.dc:creator: Becca Foley and Noah Riffe
item.media:description: Moo Deng was introduced to the world in July by the Khao Kheow Open Zoo in Thailand.

item.title: As Lebanon Reels From Israeli Attacks, the Future Is Murky for a Wounded Hezbollah
item.description: Some experts said that Israel’s onslaught had left Hezbollah in disarray. Others noted its large weapons stockpiles and history of adapting to battle Israel’s much more high-tech military.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: The rubble of a building hit by an Israeli strike in southern Lebanon on Tuesday.

item.title: Zelensky Prepares for a Tough Act at the U.N. and in Meeting with Biden
item.description: In his speech to the U.N. General Assembly on Wednesday and then a meeting with President Biden a day later, the Ukrainian president will be pleading for more military and political support.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Kyiv this month.

item.title: In Rare Graft Case in Singapore, Former Minister Pleads Guilty
item.description: S. Iswaran, the former transport minister, had maintained his innocence on the corruption charge for months but on Tuesday pleaded guilty to five lesser offenses.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: Singapore’s former transport minister, S. Iswaran, arriving at the Singaporean Supreme Court on Tuesday.

item.title: Biden Warns the World Is at an ‘Inflection Point’ Amid Global Crises
item.description: In his final U.N. speech, President Biden framed his decision to drop his bid for re-election as a lesson that “some things are more important than staying in power.”
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg and David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Joe Biden’s address to the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday combined personal touches with policy imperatives and an impassioned defense of democracy.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Israeli Airstrikes in Lebanon Kill Hundreds
item.description: Plus, vintage soccer jerseys and the memories they preserve.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:description: Tyre, in southern Lebanon, after Israeli airstrikes yesterday.

item.title: Earthquake Off Japan Coast Triggers Tsunami Advisory
item.description: The earthquake occurred off the coast of Torishima Island, which is uninhabited, at 8:14 a.m. on Tuesday, according to the Japan Meteorological Agency. The advisory was lifted at 11 a.m.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri and Hisako Ueno
item.media:description: The Japan Meteorological Agency issued tsunami advisories for the Izu and Ogasawara islands off the coast of Japan after an earthquake on Tuesday.

item.title: Israeli Strikes in Lebanon Kill Hundreds as Warplanes Target Hezbollah
item.description: It was the deadliest day in decades of hostilities between Israel and the militants, who stepped up their own barrage of rockets.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Euan Ward, Aaron Boxerman and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Southern Lebanon hit by Israeli strikes on Monday.

item.title: Russia’s Next-Generation Nuclear Missile Failed a Test, Evidence Suggests
item.description: Satellite photos showing a 200-foot-wide crater at a launch site indicate that the Sarmat missile, said by the Kremlin to travel at five times the speed of sound, might not be ready for duty.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A satellite image taken on Saturday showing a Sarmat missile launch site that was apparently damaged in an explosion during a test launch.

item.title: Biden Works Against the Clock as Violence Escalates in the Middle East
item.description: President Biden is beginning to acknowledge that he is simply running out of time to help forge a cease-fire and hostage deal with Hamas, his aides say. And the risk of a wider war has never looked greater.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: For a year now, President Biden has warned publicly and privately about the need to avoid a broader war in the Middle East, one that could easily escalate into direct conflict between Israel and Iran.

item.title: At U.N. General Assembly, Global Crises Collide With Fraught U.S. Politics
item.description: President Biden will speak at a time of deep uncertainty about the future of America’s role in the world.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine delivering remarks at the U.N. General Assembly last year. He will meet with President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris this week.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Israeli Airstrikes in Lebanon Kill Hundreds
item.description: Plus, vintage soccer jerseys and the memories they preserve.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: Tyre, southern Lebanon, after Israeli airstrikes on Monday.

item.title: Pakistan Appoints New Head of Its Powerful Spy Agency
item.description: The appointment of a top general, Lt. Gen. Muhammad Asim Malik, to the post comes as the country faces numerous internal and external challenges.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood

item.title: U.S. to Send More Troops to Middle East as Tensions Rise
item.description: Maj. Gen. Patrick S. Ryder, the Pentagon press secretary, declined to say exactly how many troops were deploying, citing operational security.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Israel has carried out a series of attacks on Hezbollah targets in recent days, raising concern in the Biden administration that retaliatory strikes by the group or Iran could endanger U.S. troops in the region.

item.title: Israel Targets Top Hezbollah Commander Ali Karaki in Beirut Strike
item.description: Hezbollah said in a statement that the chief of its forces in southern Lebanon was alive and well.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Mohamad Al Ghandour/AFPTV, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A screen grab from a video showing smoke over the southern suburbs of Beirut, Lebanon, after a strike on Monday.

item.title: A South Korean Olympian Gets to Play an Assassin, but Some Before Her Have Flopped
item.description: Olympians who tried the movies, especially in the 1980s, often fared poorly.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:description: Now that’s a movie star, right?

item.title: Tanzania Arrests Opposition Leaders Ahead of Planned Protest
item.description: The East African country’s leading opposition party said that its presidential candidate in the last election and its chairman were among dozens detained before a protest called to draw attention to the killing and abduction of government critics.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Hurtes
item.media:description: Freeman Mbowe, chairman of Tanzania’s main opposition party, Chadema, being detained by the police in Dar es Salaam on Monday.

item.title: Ukraine Needs to Be Realistic About Goals in War With Russia, Czech President Says
item.description: President Petr Pavel, a former NATO general who has been vocal in his support for Ukraine, said Kyiv needed to accept that some territory could remain under Russian control, at least “temporarily.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: President Petr Pavel of the Czech Republic at a NATO summit in Washington in July.

item.title: Biden Meets With UAE President, Mohammed bin Zayed, in Washington
item.description: The meetings with Sheikh Mohammed bin Zayed were expected to focus on Gaza, the war in Sudan and artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Ismaeel Naar
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sheikh Mohammed bin Zayed is the first Emirati president to visit American soil since the United Arab Emirates was founded in 1971.

item.title: Israel Launches Deadly Strikes Across Gaza, Local Officials Say
item.description: The latest in a series of strikes on schools being used as shelters killed three in Nuseirat, according to the Palestinian Civil Defense. Israel has said the buildings were being used by Hamas militants as a command center.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: Palestinians at Al-Aqsa Hospital in the central Gaza Strip mourning the death of relatives killed by strikes in Deir Al Balah on Monday.

item.title: Was It Really a Hot Zone Summer?
item.description: From Covid to dengue, viral outbreaks seemed to be popping up all over. But maybe Americans are just more attuned to threats now.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: Mosquitoes sickened some Americans with infections like dengue, malaria, West Nile virus and Eastern equine encephalitis. But apart from dengue, the outbreaks were not particularly bad.

item.title: Russian Military Plane Breaches Japan’s Airspace
item.description: The infringements were the first by Russia in five years, according to the Japanese defense ministry. A fighter fired a warning flare in response.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Kiuko Notoya
item.media:credit: The Asahi Shimbun, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Russian plane reportedly flew above Rebun Island, northwest of Hokkaido, Japan’s northernmost prefecture.

item.title: Man Smashes Ai Weiwei’s Porcelain Sculpture at Italian Museum
item.description: The man behind the episode, at a reception for Mr. Ai’s new exhibition in Bologna, has targeted artists before, a museum spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Genus Bononiae Press Office, via Reuters
item.media:description: “Porcelain Cube,” a piece by Ai Weiwei, was smashed to pieces at the Palazzo Fava on Friday.

item.title: Israel-Hezbollah Tensions Spiral in Week of Attacks: What to Know
item.description: Exploding pagers, a major Israeli strike in Beirut and Hezbollah attacks deep inside Israel have brought the two sides closer than they’ve been in years to a full-scale war.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A funeral in Beirut on Wednesday for people killed by the exploding devices.
